--- title: Text normalization author: Marie-Hélène Burle --- :::{.def} TextBlob allows to transform text—something very useful in preparation for text analysis. ::: :::{.callout-note collapse="true"} ## Necessary code from previous sessions Here is the necessary code from previous sessions, stripped to the minimum: ::: {#1770ae53 .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} # Load packages import requests import pymupdf from textblob import TextBlob # Download the data url = "https://funnyengwish.wordpress.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/pratchett_terry_wyrd_sisters_-_royallib_ru.pdf" response = requests.get(url) # Extract data from pdf data = response.content doc = pymupdf.Document(stream=data) # Create text from first pdf page page1 = doc[0].get_text() # Turn text into TextBlob text = TextBlob(page1) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
ModuleNotFoundError                       Traceback (most recent call last)

      1 # Load packages
      2 import requests
----> 3 import pymupdf
      4 from textblob import TextBlob
      6 # Download the data

ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'pymupdf'
``` ::: ::: ::: ::: ## Case There are methods to change the case of `TextBlob` objects. For example, capitalization (let's only print the first 1000 characters) ::: {#7cc27ade .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(text.title()[:1000]) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------

NameError: name 'text' is not defined

``` ::: ::: ::: ## Lemmatization [Lemmatization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemmatization) reduces all words to their [lemma](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lemma_(morphology)) (dictionary or canonical form) so that [inflected words](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inflection) such as "dog" and "dogs" aren't counted in separate categories in analyses. ### Nouns The `lemmatize` method uses as its default argument `"n"` (for noun): ::: {#706ec24a .cell execution_count=7} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(TextBlob("heirs").words[0].lemmatize()) print(TextBlob("daggers").words[0].lemmatize()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[6], line 1
----> 1 print(TextBlob("heirs").words[0].lemmatize())
      2 print(TextBlob("daggers").words[0].lemmatize())

NameError: name 'TextBlob' is not defined
``` ::: ::: ::: :::{.note} Be careful: you can't always trust that TextBlob will work properly. It is a library very easy to use, but it has its limitations. For instance, I am not sure why this one doesn't work: ::: {#f82bc1cd .cell execution_count=8} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(TextBlob("men").words[0].lemmatize()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}

NameError: name 'TextBlob' is not defined

``` ::: ::: ::: ## Correction The `correct` method attempts to correct spelling mistakes: ::: {#ae716a7d .cell execution_count=14} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(TextBlob("Somethingg with speling mystakes").correct()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html} 
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
Cell In[13], line 1
----> 1 print(TextBlob("Somethingg with speling mystakes").correct())

NameError: name 'TextBlob' is not defined
``` ::: ::: ::: :::{.note} There are however limitations since the method is based on a lexicon and isn't aware of the relationship between words (and thus cannot correct grammatical errors): ::: {#0c890f45 .cell execution_count=15} ``` {.python .cell-code} print(TextBlob("Some thingg with speling mystake").correct()) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ::: {.ansi-escaped-output} ```{=html}
